items.title: Iran adds 7 more years to sentence of jailed Nobel Peace laureate, supporters say
items.summary_auto: Iran sentenced Nobel Peace Prize laureate Narges Mohammadi to over seven more years in prison after she began a hunger strike, supporters said Sunday, as Tehran cracks down on all dissent following nationwide protests and the deaths of thousands at the hands of security forces.

items.title: What to expect from Bad Bunny’s Super Bowl halftime show? Dancing, culture and a side of politics
Canadian figure skater Madeline Schizas gets university assignment extension at Olympics
items.summary_auto: Canadian figure skater and McMaster University student Madeline Schizas was granted an extension on her sociology assignment one day after going viral with her request on Instagram.

items.title: Sidney Crosby named captain of Canada's men's hockey team
items.summary_auto: Two-time Olympic gold medallist Sidney Crosby was been named captain of Canada's men's hockey team at the Milan Cortina Games.

items.title: Man behind the Clarity Act has choice words for Alberta separatists and Danielle Smith
Suspect in shooting of senior Russian officer detained, Russia says
items.summary_auto: Russia’s Federal Security Service said Sunday that the man suspected of shooting a deputy chief of Russia’s military intelligence agency in Moscow was detained in Dubai and handed over to Russia.

items.title: Central Alberta clinic pioneers ‘first-of-its-kind’ sexual assault care
items.summary_auto: This ‘first-of-its-kind’ centre in Red Deer, Alta., is diverting over a third of sexual assault cases away from busy hospital emergency rooms, providing patients with a calmer and more private health experience.

items.title: Apartment residents say fatal carbon monoxide poisoning of 11-year-old was preventable
items.summary_auto: A man who lives in a Regina apartment building says the carbon monoxide detector in his unit sounded just hours before another resident, an 11-year-old boy, died.

items.title: Characters in Oscar-nominated short brought to life by award-winning actor Colm Feore at Kitchener studio
items.summary_auto: An animated Canadian film produced by the National Film Board of Canada which has been nominated for an Oscar has local connections. The Girls Who Cried Pearls is a stop-motion film that tells the story of a poor boy in early 20th century Montreal who falls in love with a girl whose tears turn into pearls. It features the voice of actor Colm Feore who recorded the 17-minute short at Fred Smith Studios in Kitchener.

items.title: Provincial officials still trying to find way to raise abandoned tidal turbine
items.summary_auto: Ten months after the Nova Scotia government’s Energy Department took the lead on finding a way to recover an abandoned tidal turbine from the depths of the Bay of Fundy, officials still cannot say when — or if — the device might be removed.

items.title: No desks, no strategy: Experts say government's latest return-to-office order ignores reality
items.summary_auto: With federal public servants mandated to return to the office four days a week this summer, experts and unions are sounding the alarm over a lack of clear strategy or infrastructure to support such a move.

items.title: Toronto's young transit enthusiasts 'bamboozled' by Eglinton Crosstown's day 1 speed
items.summary_auto: It might be a chilly day, but the cold air didn't stop excited Torontonians from piling onto the newly launched trains along Line 5 Sunday. "Line 5, Line 5, Line 5," chants erupted as the first Crosstown riders waited to get onboard at Kennedy Station.

items.title: With Maduro gone, Venezuelans test freedom to criticize leaders
items.summary_auto: Just over one month after the United States captured then-President Nicolas Maduro, some Venezuelans opposed to the government have become increasingly bold in challenging the new authorities.

items.title: Civil rights pioneer says after almost 70 years, story of the Little Rock Nine still 'resonates'
items.summary_auto: Long before her work as an anti-racist educator and environmental campaigner in Canada, Minnijean Brown-Trickey showed enormous courage as one of the Little Rock Nine — a group of Black teenagers who integrated Little Rock Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., in 1957.

items.title: How Scholastic became a cultural rite of passage for Canadian kids
items.summary_auto: For decades, Scholastic has been a fixture in Canadian elementary schools, introducing children to reading while helping fund under-resourced libraries. Despite growing criticism over cost and commercialization, the book fair remains a nostalgic — and enduring — rite of passage.

items.title: Watch these ice climbers scale Hamilton’s Tiffany Falls
items.summary_auto: Climbing company Muskoka Mountainworks took a group to Tiffany Falls in Hamilton for the first time last month. Two of the climbers tell CBC Hamilton they've long wanted to scale the frozen waterfall. They say ice climbing has been a great way for them to embrace winter.

items.title: I wanted to complete a triathlon. My first step? Learning to swim
items.summary_auto: At the age of 37, Alberto Ortiz's swimming had been casual dips in lakes or resort pools. But when a cousin made a joke about training for a triathlon, the idea stuck. When the training started, it didn't take long before he'd signed up for a full-distance Olympic triathlon.

items.title: Most of the world doesn’t require a prescription for birth control. Why do Canadians still need one?
items.summary_auto: Some Canadian doctors say patients on birth control need monitoring. But medical authorities in other countries increasingly disagree.

items.title: No place for politics in F-35 cockpits as Canadian fighter jet pilots get ready to train at U.S. base
items.summary_auto: While procurement for Canada’s complete fighter jet fleet remains up in the air, advocates say politics need to be set aside as members of the Royal Canadian Air Force head to Luke Air Force Base in Arizona later this year to train on the F-35 when Canada eventually takes possession of the 16 jets it’s committed to buying.

items.title: Why Spain is aiming to regularize half a million undocumented migrants
items.summary_auto: While the United States has intensified its immigration crackdown and deportation efforts  and European countries are closing their borders one after the other, Spain's left-wing government last month approved a royal decree to regularize several hundred thousand undocumented people who already live and work in the country.
